awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Deciphering the Genetic Diversity of Viruses through Gene Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteriophages are viruses that infect bacteria and can have a profound impact on bacterial populations. These viruses are the most abundant and diverse members of most ecosystems on Earth, having been found in every environment that supports life. The majority of the DNA sequences of newly isolated bacteriophage samples bears little or no resemblance to any sequences contained within current databases. This means that identifying new samples by looking for similar sequences is not an effective strategy. It is therefore crucial to find different approaches to characterize these viruses, which will then help is understand the critical roles that they have as members of microbial communities. This research will develop a new network-based approach for classifying viruses, thereby opening new avenues for exploring virus ecology as well as providing genomic data for evolutionary studies. This new approach will redefine how the genetic diversity of viruses is represented, making possible direct analyses of complex viral communities at higher resolution than is currently possible. Furthermore, the project will unite students from the computational and biological sciences, creating interdisciplinary teams able to carry out this research, with this training taking both in the classroom and laboratory.

The project will develop a new graphical framework for the investigation of viral metagenomes, specifically aimed at putting novel viral sequences into a global context of viral genetic diversity. Because virus genomes are mosaics of genes acquired over time from multiple sources, a 'gene-centric' rather than a 'genome-centric' approach to classify the sequences in viromes is taken. In addition to capturing the combinatorial structure of virus genomes, this approach is robust to variation in genome and contig size that can arise from diverse datasets. Through the development of novel algorithms and metrics, evolutionary and ecological signals in the data will be integrated to inform the network's structure. The network will also be used to test hypotheses driven from the data, in particular the signals of viral host-range. For more information about the project visit the PI's lab website at http://www.putonti-lab.com.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project led to the development of new approaches for examining and discovering viral genome sequences. Computational tools were developed, refined, and applied to all publicly available viral sequences as well as publicly available sequencing data sets of complex communities. Evolutionary and ecological signals of viruses were detected, providing key insights into viral host switching and adaptations associated with host-range. The power of these predictions was tested and confirmed empirically. Using these computational tools, two new bacteriophage families were discovered from public data sets and subsequently characterized. Computational analyses included microbial communities from a variety of different ecosystems. All tools developed as part of this project are publicly available for the scientific community. This project also provided numerous training opportunities for undergraduate and Masters-level students as well as one post-doctoral researcher. Laboratory and classroom experiences increased computer science competency among students that are representative of diverse genders, ethnicities, and socioeconomic groups. Students in the laboratory were engaged in algorithm development, testing, application, and bench lab experiments, thus gaining valuable hands-on experience in preparation for advanced degrees, government research, or jobs in industry. These students presented their work at area, national, and international conferences as well as co-authored manuscripts. Additionally, this project provided training opportunities within the classroom setting through new modules in didactic courses and course-based undergraduate research experiences.

 


Last Modified: 10/19/2022
Modified by: Catherine Putonti
